questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) has a negative urine microalbumin test. When should the next urine microalbumin test be repeated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) In 1 year

 

Option C:

 

Annual screening for microalbuminuria is recommended for patients with type 2 diabetes to detect early signs of diabetic nephropathy (kidney disease). A negative test result indicates no current evidence of kidney damage, therefore, the next screening should be done in a year.

 

 

Explanation

 

Option A. In 3 months: Too frequent for routine screening and not necessary with a negative initial test.

 

Option B. In 6 months: While more frequent screening may be indicated in some cases, annual testing is generally sufficient for initial monitoring.

 

Option D. In 5 years: Too infrequent for monitoring diabetic nephropathy, as significant damage could occur undetected in this time frame.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Annual screening for microalbuminuria is recommended in type 2 diabetes to detect early signs of diabetic nephropathy.

choices.text: Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with long-standing diabetes presents with the lesion shown in the image. Identify the condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diabetic dermopathy

 

Option A:

 

The image shows multiple, well-defined, hyperpigmented atrophic macules over both shins, which is characteristic of diabetic dermopathy. Diabetic dermopathy, also known as shin spots, is the most common cutaneous manifestation of diabetes mellitus. It is caused by changes in the small blood vessels of the skin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum: This condition presents as larger, yellowish-brown patches with a raised, reddish border, often located on the shins.

 

Option C. Lichen planus: This inflammatory skin condition presents as purple, itchy, flat-topped bumps.

 

Option D. Scleredema: This condition is characterized by thickening and hardening of the skin, usually on the back or neck.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diabetic dermopathy, characterized by hyperpigmented atrophic macules over the shins, is the most common cutaneous manifestation of diabetes.

choices.text: Factitious hypoglycemia due to sulfonylurea

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with recurrent hypoglycemia, confirmed by Whipple's triad. Laboratory investigations reveal a beta-hydroxybutyrate (β-OHB) level of 5 mmol/L and a poor blood glucose response to glucagon. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-insulin-mediated hypoglycemia

 

Option C:

 

Elevated β-OHB levels and Poor response to glucagon indicated that the hypoglycemia is not mediated by insulin or insulin like factors (IGF-2). Examples include critical illness, organ failure (liver, kidney), sepsis, counter-regulatory hormone deficiencies (GH/cortisol) etc.

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Insulinoma: This would typically present with suppressed ketone levels due to the inhibitory effect of excess insulin on lipolysis and ketogenesis.

 

Option B. Factitious hypoglycemia due to sulfonylurea: Sulfonylureas increase insulin secretion, and hypoglycemia due to these medications would and tend to have suppressed β-OHB (< 2.7 mmol/L) in view of hyperinsulinemia.

 

Option D. IGF-2 related hypoglycemia: This is a rare cause of hypoglycemia and tend to have suppressed β-OHB (< 2.7 mmol/L) in view of insulin like action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elevated β-OHB levels and poor response to glucagon indicate non-insulin-mediated hypoglycemia, such as critical illness or organ failure.

choices.text: Add dextrose to the intravenous fluids
Increase the rate of the insulin infusion

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with type 2 diabetes presents to the emergency department with DKA. His initial blood glucose level is 650 mg/dL. After 6 hours of treatment with intravenous fluids and insulin, his blood glucose drops to 200 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Add dextrose to the intravenous fluids

 

Option C:

 

When the blood glucose level drops to 200-250 mg/dL during DKA treatment, it is crucial to add dextrose to the intravenous fluids to prevent hypoglycemia and to maintain a target plasma glucose is 150-200 mg/dL. Insulin infusion can thus, be continued at a lower rate to ensure correction of ketoacidosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Discontinue the insulin infusion: Insulin should not be discontinued until the ketoacidosis is resolved, as indicated by a normal anion gap and beta-hydroxybutyrate level.

 

Option B. Switch to subcutaneous insulin: Subcutaneous insulin is not appropriate in the acute management of DKA.

 

Option D. Increase the rate of the insulin infusion: Increasing the insulin infusion rate could lead to hypoglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When blood glucose drops to 200-250 mg/dL during DKA treatment, add dextrose to IV fluids to prevent hypoglycemia and continue insulin infusion.

questions.text:
A young woman with type 1 diabetes presents to the emergency department with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) after stopping insulin. On examination, she is delirious and initial laboratory reports show:

 

S. Na 128 mEq/L, S. K+ 4.3 mEq/L, BUN 76 mg/dL, S. Cr 2.2 mg/dL, S. HCO3- 10 mEq/L, Blood glucose 520 mg/dL.

 

Which of the following is NOT an appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3% NaCl

 

Option A:

 

The patient presents with pseudohyponatremia, which is a falsely low sodium level due to the presence of hyperglycemia. The corrected sodium level can be calculated using the following formula:

 

Corrected Sodium = Measured Sodium + 1.6 mEq/L * (Serum Glucose [mg/dL] - 100 mg/dL) / 100

 

In this case, the corrected sodium is:

 

Corrected Sodium = 128 mEq/L + 1.6 mEq/L * (520 mg/dL - 100 mg/dL) / 100 = 135 mEq/L

 

Since the corrected sodium is within the normal range (135-145 mEq/L), administering hypertonic saline (3% NaCl) is not indicated. In fact, it could be harmful by worsening hyperosmolar state.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. 0.9% sodium chloride (NaCl): This isotonic fluid is appropriate for rehydration in DKA.

 

Option C. Insulin infusion: This is essential to lower blood glucose levels and correct ketoacidosis in DKA.

 

Option D. Potassium supplementation: While initial potassium levels are normal, they can drop rapidly with insulin therapy. Therefore, potassium supplementation is often necessary during DKA treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypertonic saline (3% NaCl) is not indicated in DKA with pseudohyponatremia; it could worsen the hyperosmolar state.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy with type 1 diabetes presents with vomiting, abdominal pain, lethargy, and drowsiness. His blood glucose is 350 mg/dL, and ABG shows the following – pH 7.24, S. Na 130 mEq/L, S. K 3.0 mEq/L, S. HCO3- 14 mEq/L, and S. Cl 88 mEq/L. His BP is 90/60 mm Hg, and IV fluids were rushed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV KCl

 

Option B:

 

The patient is presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) based on the clinical presentation (vomiting, abdominal pain, lethargy, drowsiness), elevated blood glucose (350 mg/dL), and metabolic acidosis on ABG (pH 7.24, bicarbonate 14 mEq/L). The patient also has significant hypokalemia (K+ 3.0 mEq/L) which is a common electrolyte disturbance in DKA due to increased urinary potassium loss.

 

  • Hypokalemia and Insulin: Insulin administration can further exacerbate hypokalemia by shifting potassium from the extracellular to the intracellular space. Therefore, potassium replacement should be initiated before starting insulin therapy in DKA.

 

Explanation

 

Option A. IV Aspart: Insulin therapy is essential in DKA but should be started after correcting hypokalemia. Regular insulin is preferred for IV use in view of lesser cost but rapid acting analogs can also be used for IV use and are not contraindicated.

 

Option C. IV NaHCO3: Sodium bicarbonate is generally not recommended in DKA unless the pH is less than 6.9 or there are significant cardiac complications.

 

Option D. CT head: Cerebral edema is a rare complication of DKA and usually occurs in children during treatment. It is not the immediate priority in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Administer IV potassium chloride to correct hypokalemia before initiating insulin therapy in DKA to prevent severe hypokalemia.

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory values is typically seen in hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS) and not in diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arterial pH >7.3

 

Option A:

 

In hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS), the arterial pH is typically normal or near normal (>7.3) due to the absence of significant ketoacidosis. This is in contrast to diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), where the accumulation of ketone bodies leads to metabolic acidosis and a lower arterial pH (<7.3).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Elevated plasma ketones: This is a hallmark of DKA, not HHS.

 

Option C. Osmolality <320 mOsm/mL: Hyperosmolarity can occur in both DKA and HHS but DKA patients tend to have a serum osmolality of < 320 mOsm/L. HHS patients typically have a serum osmolality of > 320 mOsm/L (due to extreme hyperglycemia).

 

Option D. Sodium <135 mEq/L: Hyponatremia (low sodium) can occur in both DKA and HHS but it is less pronounced and it is often normal in HHS (in view of severe dehydration and water loss).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HHS, the arterial pH is typically normal or near normal (>7.3) due to the absence of significant ketoacidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following complications of diabetes mellitus is due to microvascular disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Macular edema

 

Option B:

 

Diabetic Macular edema is microvascular complication of diabetes mellitus. Macular edema is a complication of diabetic retinopathy, which is a microvascular disease affecting the small blood vessels in the retina. It occurs due to increased vascular permeability and leakage of fluid into the macula, leading to blurred vision.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cheiroarthropathy: This refers to hand stiffness and joint changes, which are not primarily caused by microvascular disease.

 

Option C. Infections: While diabetes can increase susceptibility to infections, it is not a direct consequence of microvascular disease.

 

Option D. Feet Claudication: Claudication (pain with exertion) is a symptom of peripheral artery disease, which is a macrovascular complication of diabetes.

 

Summary:

 

Microvascular complications (diabetes specific): Retinopathy, macular edema, neuropathy, nephropathy (diabetic kidney disease).

 

Macrovascular complications: CAD, PAD and cerebrovascular disease.

 

Nonvascular/multifactorial complications: Infections, skin changes, cheiroarthropathy, cataract, glaucoma, periodontal disease, GI/GU complications and hearing loss. Some studies suggest that type 2 DM increases the risk of dementia and impaired cognitive function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diabetic macular edema is a microvascular complication of diabetes, caused by increased vascular permeability and fluid leakage into the macula

choices.text: Herniation of a lumbar disk

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes presents with sudden-onset, severe right thigh pain and weakness. His sensory examination is normal. MRI of the lower spine is unremarkable. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diabetic amyotrophy

 

Option A:

 

Diabetic amyotrophy (also known as diabetic lumbosacral radiculoplexus neuropathy) is a microvascular complication of diabetes that affects the nerves supplying the proximal leg muscles, causing pain, weakness, and muscle wasting.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Distal symmetric polyneuropathy: This typically affects the feet and hands first, causing sensory symptoms before motor weakness.

 

Option C. Herniation of a lumbar disk: This would usually present with radicular pain and sensory changes, which are absent in this case. Also, MRI would have revealed the herniation.

 

Option D. Meralgia paresthetica: This causes numbness and tingling in the outer thigh due to compression of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, but not severe pain or weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diabetic amyotrophy is a microvascular complication affecting the nerves supplying proximal leg muscles, causing pain and weakness.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones has a delayed response in the defense against acute hypoglycemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Release of Cortisol

 

Option B:

 

Cortisol and growth hormone although involved in glucose counter-regulation, has a delayed response. It primarily supports glucose production during prolonged hypoglycemia (lasting more than 4 hours) and thus, cortisol and growth hormone play no role in defense against acute hypoglycemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Suppression of Insulin release: First line of defense in hypoglycemia. Insulin release is reduced at plasma glucose levels of < 80-85 mg/dL and almost shuts off if levels are < 70 mg/dL.

 

Option C. Release of Glucagon: Second line of defense in acute hypoglycemia. Kicks off once glucose levels are < 65-70 mg/dL.

 

Option D. Release of Epinephrine: Import ant especially in glucagon deficient states. Kicks off once glucose levels are < 65-70 mg/dL. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cortisol has a delayed response in hypoglycemia, primarily supporting glucose production during prolonged hypoglycemia.

choices.text: Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum

questions.text: What is the most common cutaneous manifestation of diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Xerosis

 

Option B:

 

Xerosis and pruritis are the most common cutaneous manifestations of diabetes mellitus. They are usually relieved by skin moisturizers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Diabetic dermopathy:  Sometimes termed pigmented pretibial papules, or “diabetic skin spots,” begins as an erythematous macule or papule that evolves into an area of circular hyperpigmentation. These lesions result from minor mechanical trauma in the pretibial region and are more common in elderly men with DM.

 

Option C. Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum: It is an uncommon disorder, accompanying diabetes in predominantly young women. This usually begins in the pretibial region as an erythematous plaque or papules that gradually enlarge, darken, and develop irregular margins, with atrophic centers and central ulceration. They are often painful.

 

Option D. Acanthosis nigricans: This is a velvety, hyperpigmented skin condition associated with insulin resistance. It is not the most common skin finding in diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xerosis (dry skin) and pruritis are the most common cutaneous manifestations of diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus undergoes an ophthalmologic examination. What is the most likely finding seen on his funduscopic examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neovascularization

 

Option B:

 

The funduscopic image shows characteristic signs of proliferative diabetic retinopathy, the most significant of which is neovascularization. This is the growth of new blood vessels on the retina, which are fragile and prone to bleeding, leading to vision loss.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Microaneurysms: While microaneurysms are an early sign of diabetic retinopathy, they are not the defining characteristic of proliferative retinopathy seen in this image.

 

Option C. Papilledema: This is swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure and is not associated with diabetic retinopathy.

 

Option D. Retinal detachment: While a potential complication of proliferative diabetic retinopathy, it is not directly visible in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neovascularization is the hallmark of proliferative diabetic retinopathy, characterized by the growth of new blood vessels on the retina.

choices.text: Change statins to PCSK9 inhibitor

questions.text: A 44-year-old diabetic patient with CAD presents to you with routine blood tests. His LDL levels were within target (68 mg/dL) but his triglyceride levels were elevated (350 mg/dL). What can be done next to reduce his CV risk?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Add Icosapent ethyl

 

Option C:

 

The patient has hypertriglyceridemia (triglycerides >150 mg/dL) despite being on statin therapy and having LDL cholesterol under control. Icosapent ethyl is a highly purified form of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), an omega-3 fatty acid, that has been shown to significantly reduce cardiovascular risk in patients with elevated triglyceride levels, even when already on statin therapy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increase dose of statins: While statins can modestly lower triglycerides, their primary effect is on LDL cholesterol. Increasing the statin dose may not significantly reduce triglycerides and could increase the risk of side effects.

 

Option B. Add fenofibrate: Fibrates can effectively lower triglycerides, but they have not been shown to reduce cardiovascular events in patients already on statin therapy.

 

Option D. Change statins to PCSK9 inhibitor: PCSK9 inhibitors are potent LDL-lowering drugs but have limited effects on triglycerides. They would not be the most appropriate choice in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Icosapent ethyl, an omega-3 fatty acid, significantly reduces cardiovascular risk in patients with elevated triglycerides despite being on statin therapy.

choices.text: Rapid control of blood sugars

questions.text: All of the following result in worsening of diabetic retinopathy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fenofibrate

 

Option B:

 

Fenofibrate, a fibrate medication used to treat dyslipidemia, has been shown to have a potential beneficial effect on diabetic retinopathy. It may help reduce the progression of the disease by lowering triglyceride levels and improving blood lipid profiles.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rapid control of blood sugars: While tight glycemic control is essential for the long-term management of diabetic retinopathy, rapid improvement in blood sugar levels can sometimes lead to a temporary worsening of retinopathy in the short term (6-12 months). Individuals with known retinopathy may be candidates for prophylactic laser photocoagulation when initiating intensive therapy, and especially prior to pancreas or islet transplantation that can rapidly normalize glycemia.

 

Option C. Pregnancy: Hormonal changes and increased metabolic demands during pregnancy can exacerbate diabetic retinopathy.

 

Option D. Diabetic nephropathy: Kidney disease in diabetes is often associated with worsened retinopathy due to shared microvascular damage and potential alterations in growth factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fenofibrate may help reduce the progression of diabetic retinopathy by lowering triglyceride levels and improving blood lipid profiles.

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT occur in diabetic autonomic neuropathy (DAN)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased heart rate variability

 

Option A:

 

DAN typically causes decreased heart rate variability due to impaired autonomic regulation of the heart. This is a significant finding that can be detected on electrocardiogram (ECG) or Holter monitoring.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Orthostatic hypotension: This is a common feature of DAN due to impaired sympathetic nervous system response, leading to a drop in blood pressure upon standing.

 

Option C. Resting tachycardia: This is also frequently seen in DAN due to parasympathetic dysfunction, leading to a faster resting heart rate.

 

Option D. Prolonged QT interval: DAN can affect cardiac conduction, leading to a prolonged QT interval and increased risk of arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased heart rate variability is seen in DAN due to impaired autonomic regulation of the heart.

choices.text: Most common form is DSPN (Distal Symmetric Polyneuropathy)
Glycemic control can worsen neuropathic pain initially
Loss of knee jerk is common

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding diabetic neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Loss of knee jerk is common

 

Option D:

 

Diabetic neuropathy often affects the longest nerves first, which are the peripheral nerves in the feet and legs. The loss of ankle jerk reflexes is a common finding, while the knee jerk reflex is typically preserved.

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Most common form is DSPN: This is true. DSPN is the most prevalent form of diabetic neuropathy.

 

Option B. Glycemic control can worsen neuropathic pain initially: This is true. In some cases, rapid improvement in glycemic control can paradoxically worsen neuropathic pain in the short term.

 

Option C. Patients can be asymptomatic: Many patients (up to 50%) with diabetic neuropathy, especially in the early stages, do not experience any symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diabetic neuropathy typically affects the peripheral nerves in the feet and legs first, with loss of ankle jerk reflexes being common.

questions.text: A patient with type 1 diabetes presents with vomiting, abdominal pain and tachycardia. Which laboratory finding would be consistent with the diagnosis of euglycemic ketoacidosis (EDKA)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Beta-hydroxybutyrate (β-OHB) level of 5 mmol/L

 

Option D:

 

Euglycemic ketoacidosis (EDKA) is a form of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) where ketone levels are elevated, leading to metabolic acidosis, but blood glucose levels are near normal or only slightly elevated.

 

  • β-OHB level of 5 mmol/L: Elevated beta-hydroxybutyrate is a key ketone body and a hallmark of ketoacidosis.
  • The symptoms of vomiting and abdominal pain are common in DKA and EDKA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Blood sugar of 340 mg/dL: This is a high blood sugar level, typical of DKA, not EDKA.

 

Option B. Serum bicarbonate of 22 mEq/L: This is a normal HCO3- level and wouldn't indicate acidosis.

 

Option C. Anion gap of 8 mEq/L: This is a normal anion gap and wouldn't indicate acidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elevated β-OHB levels indicate ketoacidosis, even when blood glucose levels are near normal, characteristic of euglycemic ketoacidosis.

choices.text: Malignant otitis externa

questions.text: Which of the following infection is a hallmark of diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malignant otitis externa

 

Option A:

 

Malignant (invasive) otitis externa is a severe, potentially life-threatening infection of the external ear canal. It is particularly associated with diabetes mellitus, especially in older adults. Invasive otitis externa is usually secondary to Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection.

 

  • Many common infections are more frequent and severe in the diabetic population, whereas several rare infections are seen almost exclusively in the diabetic population.
  • Examples of this latter category include rhinocerebral mucormycosis, emphysematous infections of the gallbladder and urinary tract, and “malignant” or invasive otitis externa.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. UTI: While urinary tract infections (UTIs) are more common in people with diabetes, they are not considered a hallmark infection.

 

Option C. Pneumonia: Pneumonia can occur in people with diabetes, but it's not specific to this condition.

 

Option D. Tuberculosis: Diabetes can increase the risk of tuberculosis (TB), but it's not a hallmark infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignant otitis externa, a severe ear infection often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, is particularly associated with diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman with diabetes, hypertension, retinopathy, and peripheral neuropathy presents with 6 weeks of dull aching foot pain. Examination reveals bounding pulses and elevated temperature in the left foot, but no ulcers. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Charcot neuroarthropathy

 

Option B:

 

Charcot neuroarthropathy is a degenerative joint disease often associated with diabetes and neuropathy. It presents with chronic, dull pain, bounding pulses, and increased temperature in the affected foot, even without ulcers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Abscess/cellulitis: Typically presents with acute pain, redness, and swelling.

 

Option C. Diabetic foot osteomyelitis: Usually associated with fever and elevated inflammatory markers.

 

Option D. Traumatic fracture: Requires a history of trauma and would present with more acute pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Charcot neuroarthropathy presents with chronic dull pain, bounding pulses, and increased temperature in the foot, often associated with diabetes and neuropathy.

choices.text: Administer intravenous regular insulin at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Correct hypokalemia with intravenous potassium chloride before initiating insulin therapy
Administer intravenous sodium bicarbonate to correct acidosis
Obtain a head CT scan to rule out cerebral edema

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy with type 1 diabetes presents with vomiting, abdominal pain, lethargy and drowsiness. His blood glucose is 350 mg/dL, and ABG shows the following – pH 7.24, S. Na 130 mEq/L, S. K 3.0 mEq/L, S. HCO3- 14 mEq/L and S. Cl 88 mEq/L. His BP is 90/60 mm Hg and IV fluids were started. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Correct hypokalemia with intravenous potassium chloride before initiating insulin therapy

 

Option B:

 

The patient presents with DKA and hypokalemia. Hypokalemia is a common complication of DKA and can be life-threatening if not corrected before initiating insulin therapy. Insulin drives potassium into cells, potentially worsening hypokalemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Administer intravenous regular insulin at 0.1 units/kg/hour: While insulin is necessary for DKA management, it should not be initiated before correcting hypokalemia.

 

Option C. Administer intravenous sodium bicarbonate to correct acidosis: Sodium bicarbonate is generally not recommended in DKA unless the pH is less than 6.9 or there is significant cardiac instability.

 

Option D. Obtain a head CT scan to rule out cerebral edema: Cerebral edema is a rare but serious complication of DKA, but it is not the most appropriate next step in management in this patient with hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Correct hypokalemia before initiating insulin therapy in DKA to prevent further potassium depletion and cardiac complications.

questions.text: Which among the following situations is glucagon most effective?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypoglycemia in type 1 diabetes

 

Option B:

 

Glucagon works by stimulating glycogenolysis > gluconeogenesis, causing blood sugar levels to rise. Glucagon also stimulates insulin release from β cells; however, since patients with type 1 diabetes lack insulin production, glucagon can effectively raise blood glucose levels without an increase in insulin. Hence, it is an effective treatment for hypoglycemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alcohol-induced hypoglycemia: Alcohol impairs gluconeogenesis and most patients will be glycogen depleted (due to malnutrition) limiting the effectiveness of glucagon.

 

Option C. Sulfonylurea-related hypoglycemia: Glucagon stimulate insulin release which can have a synergistic effect with sulfonylureas and can cause rebound severe hypoglycemia.

 

Option D. Hypoglycemia due to insulinoma: Glucagon stimulate excessive insulin release from insulinoma which can result in dangerous hypoglycemia and hence contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucagon effectively raises blood glucose levels in hypoglycemia by stimulating glycogenolysis, especially in type 1 diabetes where there is no insulin production.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with weight gain and recurrent hypoglycemia. Laboratory investigations reveal a low beta-hydroxybutyrate (β-OHB) level (0.2 mmol/L). His C-peptide and plasma insulin levels are elevated. Urine and blood sulfonylurea screen is negative. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CECT Abdomen

 

Option A:

 

The patient's presentation and laboratory results strongly suggest an insulinoma, a neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas that secretes insulin, leading to hypoglycemia.

 

  • Weight gain and hypoglycemia: Classic symptoms of insulinoma.
  • Low β-OHB: Indicates the body is not breaking down fats for energy due to excess insulin.
  • Elevated C-peptide and insulin: Confirms endogenous insulin overproduction.
  • Negative sulfonylurea screen: Rules out medication-induced hypoglycemia.

 

The next step is to localize the tumor with imaging. CECT Abdomen (contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the abdomen) is the most sensitive imaging modality for detecting insulinomas.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Selective arterial calcium stimulation: SACST (selective arterial calcium stimulation test) can be used if biochemical profile suggests endogenous hyperinsulinism but imaging is normal (to differentiate small insulinomas vs nesidioblastosis).

 

Option C. Measure serum IGF 2 levels: IGF-2 elevation would result in reflex suppression of endogenous insulin (hence insulin levels would be low).

 

Option D. Test for insulin autoantibodies: This test is used for diagnosing autoimmune hypoglycemia, which is not supported by the clinical and laboratory findings in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CECT Abdomen is the most sensitive imaging modality for detecting insulinomas in patients presenting with weight gain, hypoglycemia, and elevated insulin/C-peptide levels.
